title: Multinomial numbers
text:
You may perhaps know how to find the last nonzero digit of n factorial. This time your task is harder, find the last nonzero decimal digit of the multinomial coefficient: (a1+ a2+ ... + an)! / (a1! × a2! × ... × an!).Note that this is an extension of the classical problem, since factorials (and binomial numbers) are also multinomial numbers!InputAn integerT, denoting the number of testcases (T≤ 10000). In each line you are given one positive integer (n ≤ 20), followed by n integers: a1, a2... an, where 0 ≤ ai≤ 1000000000. There are 4 input sets.OutputOutputTlines, the case number followed by the last nonzero decimal digit. See the sample output for the correct format!ExampleInput:7
1 0
2 11 9
4 5 7 2 9
3 1000 3000 2000
3 100000000 200000000 300000000
2 4 9
8 1 1 4 7 4 8 9 2Output:Case 1: 1
Case 2: 6
Case 3: 8
Case 4: 6
Case 5: 2
Case 6: 5
Case 7: 4Warning: A naive algorithm will probably solve only the first two input sets.
